sentences.text: what's going on guys?
Hey, good morning, Cole.
Good to see you again.
Morning.
How are you?
I'm.
good.
How are you doing?
Doing well, doing well.
Can't complain?
I don't think Jen is joining.
I also don't think Kevin is joining.
So, it's just Ali and I today.
Okay.
Got it.

And I did bring in Manoj on our side, who's going to assist us, you know, answering any questions that you might have, maybe help us create some automations, things along those lines that we can kind of talk through.
I'll let Manoj introduce himself and then we can, you know, jump into your environment and see how we can, you know, jumpstart some of the testing.
Fantastic.
Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you, Hali, so I'm Manoj as Cole said, I'll be the onboarding and the solutions engineer for you guys.
So, anything related to your implementation onboardings and team trainings, I'll be there to assist you through the way.
Fantastic.

We've been playing obviously the platform a little bit here and there we've got a shared inbox set up, I think obviously like because we already have so many existing communications already in flight.
I think one of our biggest understandings still is how do all these things get transferred?
Seamlessly?

A lot of our team uses like the labeling tool today, obviously in Gmail, where we use like parent labels to label emails by customer and then sub labels to those parents by project that's typically like a structure.
Hali, agree with me.
If you use something different that's typical across the board, we want to see things, you know, segmented that way.

And so we are imagining for our implementation which I can't imagine is too special from your other customers is like each shared inbox is designated to a logo, but within there they're project specific tags.
So that way we can still cut a full inbox across a logo or a client account by the different projects within there.
And some projects, some clients can have one to five projects.
Some clients can have upward of 20 plus.
So we want to be really clean on like understanding what we can do to potentially auto tag those emails as we go forward.
But taking existing comms and putting them into shared inboxes is going to be a big lift.
And I was seeing it really only potentially on an individual email thread basis and not being able to kind of dump things in there.
So if you're aware of like how to do that in a bulk situation, I think that's a good place to start.
Okay?
Okay.
So these emails are there in every individual user's inbox.
Yeah, because right?
For now, we've had no other email tooling.
So I'm happy to share a screen and maybe walk you through what we're talking about.
Okay, awesome.
Let's see here.
Everyone can see my inbox, right?
So, for example, you know, American eagle is a client of ours and so we have individual projects within them.
So we have here like per our labeling tool, a client level label and then individually chat child labels underneath them for the individual projects.
And so what I did was I set up this American eagle shared inbox, and I'm thinking, okay, well, how can I like migrate some of, these comms already into this?
And is it as simple as like, you know, I think I would have to individually move them but I'm not sure.
So I think that's a great first place to start.
Like, is there a better way besides like clicking in?
And I think I saw like you can add to shared inbox, but there's no way to data dump everything.
Okay.
So now, the American eagle shared mailbox that you have set up, what kind of account it is?
Is it a Google group or an individual user account?
It's a Google group.
I believe that's how we set it up.
Okay.
And you are part of the group, right?
Yes.
Okay.
Then, you know, we can just do a simple import from the back end which will push all of those emails into the shared mailbox, you don't have to do that.
Manually from your back end?
Yes.
Okay.
So that's something that you guys would have to do?
Yeah, because since it's a Google group, right?
Yeah.
And, you know, being part of the group, what hiver will actually do is it'll check for the, you know, the main person's inbox, that is you?
Yes.
And it'll sync the emails, which has the shared mailbox email address, that is the American eagle email address.
Yeah.
So, now, since all those previous email, those old emails are part of your account, you being the primary user, we can fetch it from, you know, we have an import script that we run for our customers.
Awesome.
Right.
So, yeah, we just have to, you just have to give us the exact label name and we'll trigger the import using the engineering team's bandwidth and push those emails into the mailbox.
All right.
I'm just picking our like Google admin who's like, you know, our it's like the admin that helps set it up.

I'm pretty sure that's how he set it up, but I want to make sure like.
Okay.
And if I may, yes.

Exactly how we would share that information with you?
Just so I understand.
For the import process?

Is it that simple?
Yeah.

None of the others have to create.
The tags are automatically shared with the team and emails have to be pushed into the correct tags that they give us.
That makes sense.
So, like Ali for example, because like her and I both work in American eagle projects and we're mostly on all the same communication.
So I'd probably not want to like push her American eagles and mine because then we could have potentially double communications in the shared inbox.
Is that also correct?

Okay?

I could see that happening.
Like would there be doubling in the inbox as well?
Okay.
So it's not going to be doubling in the inbox.
It's still going to be one email, but let's say you add your set of hiver tags and Ali adds a set of hiver tags.
It's just going to be multiple tags on a single email, but it's just still one email.

And then once now it has the hiver tag associated to it and it's living in the shared inbox and it's closed status, then there's no more maintenance for us because it's already now associated to the shared inbox as well.
And if you get a new email on that thread, it then becomes an open item that you can start to address again.
Yep.
Now, okay.
Okay.

Tell me.
